{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3744811,"name":"Edan Liahovetsky","username":"Etherex","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/etherex/{size}/270323_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-22T02:45:16.520Z","cooked":"

I love Cursor, and if you’ve tried it, there’s a good chance you do too. However, there’s no official community solution to get Cursor working seamlessly with WPILib and its extensions, often requiring users to maintain a separate instance of the built-in WPILib VS Code for simulation and deployment while using Cursor for development. Here’s a simple workaround to integrate them on Mac, so you can develop, simulate, and deploy from one Cursor window.

1. Install WPILib with the “Everything” option—you want it to include VS Code. If already done, proceed to step 2.

2. Install Cursor—shocker!

3. Navigate to ~/wpilib/2025/vscode and delete the vscode app. Replace it with your Cursor install. You may need to run “mv /Applications/Cursor.app ~/wpilib/2025/vscode/” in the terminal to forcefully move Cursor - out with the old, in with the new.

4. Open Cursor and complete the initial setup process.

5. Open ~/wpilib/2025/vsCodeExtensions and Cursor’s Extensions view (Cmd+Shift+X). Drag all .vsix files into the Extensions sidebar in Cursor. You should see the WPILib suite of extensions install.

6. Check for extension updates and apply if needed.

7. Restart Cursor.

8. That’s it!

This isn’t official and may have unforeseen compatibility issues. That said, it’s worked flawlessly for me over the past two months. If you’re on Mac and love Cursor (or want to try it with WPILib), give this a go. Reply with issues, clarifications, or other workarounds!

Note: I couldn’t get this working on Windows, likely due to how macOS packages apps into self-contained bundles vs. Windows’ directory-based structure. The dual-window method is still viable there.
